tools.name: McKinsey 7S
tools.description: Analyzes a company's “organizational design.” The goal of the model is to depict how effectiveness can be achieved in an organization through the interactions of seven key elements – Structure, Strategy, Skill, System, Shared Values, Style, and Staff.
tools.sovaContext: Holistic organisational alignment tool. Use when startups are scaling and need to ensure all 7 elements (Strategy, Structure, Systems, Shared Values, Style, Staff, Skills) work together. Particularly valuable for founders transitioning from startup to scaleup phase.

tools.name: Cynefin
tools.description: The Cynefin, pronounced "ku-nev-in," framework is a conceptual framework used to aid decision-making. Cynefin is divided into 5 domains: Clear, Complicated, Complex, Chaotic and Disorder (which in this case has a sense of disorientation, Confusion, rather than mess). By analyzing a situation and understanding its context, we can categorize it into each of the domains and make the most effective decision.
tools.sovaContext: Decision-making framework for complex environments. Helps founders identify whether their challenge is Simple, Complicated, Complex, or Chaotic - each requiring different approaches. Critical for pivoting decisions and market uncertainty.

tools.name: Value chain
tools.description: A value chain is a progression of activities that a firm operating in a specific industry performs in order to deliver a valuable product to the end customer.
tools.sovaContext: Maps all activities from raw inputs to customer delivery. Essential for startups to identify where they add unique value and where to optimise costs. Use before seeking investment to demonstrate operational understanding.

tools.name: Value proposition canvas
tools.description: The value proposition canvas is a framework that helps designers ensure that there is a fit between the product-service idea and the market.
tools.sovaContext: Links product features to customer needs. Core Lean Startup tool - use before building anything to validate product-market fit. Maps Customer Jobs, Pains, Gains to your Value Map (Products, Pain Relievers, Gain Creators).

tools.name: TQM
tools.description: A management framework based on the belief that an organization can build long-term success by having all its members -- from low-level workers to its highest-ranking executives -- focus on improving quality and, thus, delivering customer satisfaction.
tools.sovaContext: Organisation-wide quality culture. More relevant for scaleups than early startups. Focus on customer satisfaction metrics and continuous improvement mindset. Foundation for ISO certification journey.

tools.name: Business excellence framework
tools.description: An integrated leadership and management system that describes the elements essential to organisations sustaining high performance levels. It can be used to assess and improve any aspect of an organisation, including leadership, strategy and planning, people, information and knowledge, safety, service delivery, product quality and bottom-line results.
tools.sovaContext: Sova's foundational framework. The Australian Business Excellence Framework (ABEF) provides the integrated leadership and management system that Sova's 9 Elements are built upon. Use for comprehensive organisational assessment.

tools.name: Prosci ADKAR® Model
tools.description: The word “ADKAR” is an acronym for the five outcomes an individual needs to achieve for a change to be successful: Awareness, Desire, Knowledge, Ability and Reinforcement.
tools.sovaContext: Individual change management model. Use when implementing significant changes - new systems, processes, or culture shifts. Addresses Awareness, Desire, Knowledge, Ability, Reinforcement. Essential for startup pivots affecting team.

tools.name: Business process management (BPM)
tools.description: The discipline in which people use various methods to discover, model, analyze, measure, improve, optimize, and automate business processes. Any combination of methods used to manage a company's business processes is BPM.
tools.sovaContext: Discipline of optimising business processes. Relevant when startups have established repeatable processes that need documentation and improvement. Precursor to automation and scaling operations.

tools.name: Theory of Constraints (TOC)
tools.description: A methodology for identifying the most important limiting factor (i.e., constraint) that stands in the way of achieving a goal and then systematically improving that constraint until it is no longer the limiting factor.
tools.sovaContext: Identifies and resolves bottlenecks. Powerful for startups with limited resources - focus all effort on the ONE constraint limiting growth. Ask: 'What single thing, if improved, would have the greatest impact?'

tools.name: Six Sigma
tools.description: A set of methodologies and tools used to improve business processes by reducing defects and errors, minimizing variation, and increasing quality and efficiency.
tools.sovaContext: Data-driven defect reduction methodology. More relevant for manufacturing/scaleups than early startups. DMAIC approach useful for systematic problem-solving once processes are established.

tools.name: Design thinking
tools.description: Design thinking is a non-linear, iterative process that teams use to understand users, challenge assumptions, redefine problems and create innovative solutions to prototype and test. Involving five phases—Empathize, Define, Ideate, Prototype and Test—it is most useful to tackle problems that are ill-defined or unknown.
tools.sovaContext: Human-centred innovation process. Core startup methodology - Empathise with customers before building. The 5 phases (Empathise, Define, Ideate, Prototype, Test) align perfectly with Lean Startup validation.

tools.name: Double Diamond
tools.description: The Double Diamond is a structured design approach to tackle challenges in four phases: Discover /Research— insight into the problem (diverging) Define/Synthesis — the area to focus upon (converging) Develop/ Ideation— potential solutions (diverging) Deliver /Implementation— solutions that work (converging)
tools.sovaContext: Diverge-converge design process. Useful for startups to avoid solution-jumping. First diamond: understand the problem (Discover, Define). Second diamond: solve the problem (Develop, Deliver). Prevents building wrong thing.

tools.name: Human centred design
tools.description: Human-centered design is a practice where designers focus on four key aspects. They focus on people and their context. They seek to understand and solve the right problems, the root problems. They understand that everything is a complex system with interconnected parts. Finally, they do small interventions.
tools.sovaContext: Design with users, not for users. Foundation of successful products. Involves users throughout development, not just at testing. Essential mindset for customer discovery and product development.

tools.name: SCRUM
tools.description: An agile project management framework that helps teams structure and manage their work through a set of values, principles, and practices.
tools.sovaContext: Agile framework for iterative delivery. Ideal for product development teams. Sprints, standups, and retrospectives keep startups focused and adaptive. Works best with dedicated team of 5-9 people.

tools.name: DFSS / DMADV
tools.description: Design for Six Sigma is a collection of best-practices for the development of new products and processes.
tools.sovaContext: Design for Six Sigma - building quality into new products. More relevant for hardware/manufacturing startups. Define, Measure, Analyse, Design, Verify approach ensures new products meet customer requirements.

tools.name: Prince / PRINCE2
tools.description: a structured project management method[1] and practitioner certification programme. PRINCE2 emphasises dividing projects into manageable and controllable stages.
tools.sovaContext: Structured project governance framework. Heavyweight for most startups but useful concepts: business case justification, defined roles, stage gates. Consider for large funded projects or government contracts.

tools.name: Agile
tools.description: a project management approach that involves breaking the project into phases and emphasizes continuous collaboration and improvement. Teams follow a cycle of planning, executing, and evaluating.
tools.sovaContext: Iterative, adaptive project approach. Essential startup mindset - respond to change over following a plan. Values working product, customer collaboration, and embracing change. Foundation for modern product development.

tools.name: Kubler Ross Change curve
tools.description: The Change Curve is a model organizations can use to understand the different stages people and the organization go through when a change occurs. There are four key stages people tend to go through as they experience change. These are: shock/denial, anger/fear, acceptance, and commitment.
tools.sovaContext: Emotional stages of change. Helps founders understand team reactions to pivots, restructures, or rapid growth. Anticipate shock, denial, frustration before acceptance and commitment. Don't rush people through stages.

tools.name: Lewin's change process
tools.description: A three-stage model to change organizational behavior. The three stages are: Unfreeze, Change, Refreeze
tools.sovaContext: Unfreeze-Change-Refreeze model. Simple but powerful - you must first unfreeze current behaviours before change can occur. Use when introducing new ways of working. Don't skip the 'unfreeze' preparation.

tools.name: Kotter's 8 Step Model of Change
tools.description: 8 Step Model of Change includes: creating a sense of urgency, forming powerful guiding coalitions, developing a vision and a strategy, communicating the vision, removing obstacles and empowering employees for action, creating short-term wins, consolidating gains and strengthening change by anchoring change in the culture.
tools.sovaContext: Comprehensive change leadership framework. Starts with urgency and coalition-building before vision. Useful for larger startups implementing significant transformation. Don't skip early steps or declare victory too soon.

tools.name: Lippitt-Knoster change management model
tools.description: The Lippitt-Knoster change management model identifies the elements required for effective change: vision, consensus, skills, incentives, resources, and an action plan.
tools.sovaContext: Diagnostic tool for failed change. If change fails, identify what's missing: Vision, Consensus, Skills, Incentives, Resources, or Action Plan. Each missing element produces different symptoms (confusion, resistance, anxiety, etc.).

tools.name: Sostac
tools.description: SOSTAC is a marketing model comprises six key stages, each vital in shaping a robust marketing strategy: Situation Analysis, Objectives, Strategy, Tactics, Actions, and Control.
tools.sovaContext: Marketing planning framework. Situation, Objectives, Strategy, Tactics, Actions, Control. Provides structure for marketing plans - especially useful when seeking investment to show systematic marketing approach.

tools.name: Project management triangle
tools.description: A project management triangle is a project management model. It proposes that managing three constraints—cost, scope and time—leads to a quality final deliverable.
tools.sovaContext: Scope-Time-Cost trade-offs. Startups must choose two - you can't have fast, cheap, AND comprehensive. Use to set realistic expectations with stakeholders and make conscious trade-off decisions.

tools.name: Porter’s Five Forces Model
tools.description:
A business strategy model that organizations use to understand more about the main competitive forces at work in their industry.
Porter's Five Forces include: Competitive Rivalry, Supplier Power, Buyer Power, Threat of Substitution, and Threat of New Entry.
tools.sovaContext: Industry competitive analysis. Essential before entering a market - analyse Rivalry, Supplier Power, Buyer Power, Substitutes, and New Entrants. Helps identify if an industry is attractive and where to compete.

tools.name: Hambrick and Fredrickson’s Strategy Diamond
tools.description: A collection of the five elements forming a coherent business strategy. These five elements of strategy include Arenas, Differentiators, Vehicles, Staging, and Economic Logic.
tools.sovaContext: Five elements of coherent strategy. Ensures strategic choices align: Arenas (where to compete), Vehicles (how to get there), Differentiators (how to win), Staging (speed/sequence), Economic Logic (how to profit).

tools.name: BCG Growth-Share Matrix
tools.description: A planning tool that uses graphical representations of a company's products and services in an effort to help the company decide what it should keep, sell, or invest more in.
tools.sovaContext: Portfolio prioritisation tool. Classifies products/services as Stars, Cash Cows, Question Marks, or Dogs. Helps startups decide where to invest, maintain, or divest. More relevant with multiple product lines.

tools.name: Ansoff Matrix
tools.description: Helps marketers identify opportunities to grow revenue for a business through developing new products and services or "tapping into" new markets.
tools.sovaContext: Growth strategy options. Four paths: Market Penetration (existing product/market), Product Development, Market Development, or Diversification. Helps startups choose growth direction and understand associated risks.

tools.name: ISO9001
tools.description: The ISO 9001:2015 standard is the internationally benchmarked quality management system standard that used by organisations of all sizes and industries, all over the world.
tools.sovaContext: Quality management certification. Often required for B2B, government, or enterprise sales. Signals operational maturity. Significant investment - consider when customer contracts require it or preparing for scale.

tools.name: B corp
tools.description: B Corp Certification is a designation that a business is meeting high standards of verified performance, accountability, and transparency on factors from employee benefits and charitable giving to supply chain practices and input materials.
tools.sovaContext: Certified social/environmental accountability. Growing importance for conscious consumers and ESG-focused investors. Rigorous certification covering governance, workers, community, environment, and customers.

tools.name: Golden circle
tools.description: It is a leadership and communication concept based on the idea that great leaders and organizations inspire action by communicating their "why" (their purpose), rather than just focusing on the "what" or "how" of their actions
tools.sovaContext: Start with Why communication model. Powerful for startup storytelling - people buy WHY you do it, not what you do. Structure pitches: Why (belief) → How (approach) → What (product). Simon Sinek's TED talk essential viewing.

tools.name: Theory x and theory y
tools.description: Theory X managers believe their employees lack creativity and only work for a paycheck. Theory Y is a participative management style where managers believe employees want to work and make decisions with less supervision.
tools.sovaContext: Management philosophy about employee motivation. Theory X = people avoid work (command/control). Theory Y = people seek responsibility (empower/trust). Startups thrive with Theory Y - hire people you trust and give autonomy.

tools.name: Capability / Process Maturity Model
tools.description: Assesses what level of knowledge and documentation exists for the current state processes. The scale has 5 incremental levels where each level builds on the governance, ownership, documented processes and performance metrics.
tools.sovaContext: 5-level process maturity assessment. Level 1 (Ad hoc) → Level 5 (Optimising). Helps startups understand current state and roadmap for process improvement. Sova's maturity stages align with this progression.

tools.name: Eisenhower matrix
tools.description: The Eisenhower Matrix, also known as Urgent-Important Matrix, is a decision making principle and productivity tool that helps prioritize your many tasks. The four quadrants with this simple framework: Do, decide, delegate, and don’t do (or delete).
tools.sovaContext: Priority management for founders. Urgent vs Important creates 4 quadrants: Do (urgent+important), Schedule (important, not urgent), Delegate (urgent, not important), Delete. Founders must protect Quadrant 2 time.

tools.name: Action priority matrix
tools.description:
An action priority matrix is a graphic you can use to determine the priority level of each task in a given project. It has four squares with intersecting labels that refer to different task characteristics: Quick wins (high impact, low effort)
Major projects (high impact, high effort)
Fill-ins (low impact, low effort)
Thankless tasks (low impact, high effort)
tools.sovaContext: Impact vs Effort prioritisation. Quick Wins (high impact, low effort) first. Then Major Projects (high impact, high effort). Fill-ins when time permits. Avoid Thankless Tasks (low impact, high effort). Resource-constrained startup essential.

tools.name: PDSA Cycle
tools.description: PDSA, or Plan-Do-Study-Act, is an iterative, four-stage problem-solving model used for improving a process or carrying out change.
tools.sovaContext: Plan-Do-Study-Act continuous improvement. Deming's improvement cycle. Small, rapid experiments with learning loops. Perfect for startup iteration - plan hypothesis, test it, study results, act on learning, repeat.

tools.name: DMAIC
tools.description: Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control is a DMAIC acronym. The process includes five phases: defining the problem, improving the activity, identifying the opportunities for improvement, setting project goals, and meeting the needs of the customer (internal and external)
tools.sovaContext: Define-Measure-Analyse-Improve-Control problem-solving. Structured approach to process improvement. More rigorous than PDSA. Use when you have data and need systematic root cause analysis.

tools.name: SWOT
tools.description: SWOT stands for Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats, and so a SWOT analysis is a technique for assessing these four aspects of your business.
tools.sovaContext: Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats analysis. Simple strategic planning starting point. Internal (S/W) vs External (O/T). Use to inform strategy but don't stop here - pair with action planning.

tools.name: Value Stream Mapping
tools.description: Value-stream mapping, also known as material- and information-flow mapping, is a lean-management method for analyzing the current state and designing a future state for the series of events that take a product or service from the beginning of the specific process until it reaches the customer.
tools.sovaContext: Visualise end-to-end process flow. Shows material and information flow, highlights waste and delays. Essential for identifying where value is added vs lost. Use before process redesign or automation.

tools.name: 8 Wastes
tools.description: Establish the most likely areas where waste will occur: defects, overproduction, transportation, non-value adding processing, motion, waiting, unused talent and inventory.
tools.sovaContext: TIMWOODS waste categories: Transport, Inventory, Motion, Waiting, Overproduction, Overprocessing, Defects, Skills (unused). Lean thinking foundation. Startups should especially watch for overproduction (building unwanted features).

tools.name: Fishbone diagram (AKA Cause and Effect Diagrams or Ishikawa Diagrams)
tools.description: Bbreak down (in successive layers of detail) root causes that potentially contribute to a particular effect
tools.sovaContext: Root cause analysis visualisation. Structured brainstorming of causes across categories (People, Process, Equipment, Materials, Environment, Management). Use when problems keep recurring to find true root cause.

tools.name: 5S
tools.description: Cyclical methodology: sort, set in order, shine, standardize, sustain the cycle which results in continuous improvement.
tools.sovaContext: Workplace organisation method: Sort, Set in Order, Shine, Standardise, Sustain. Creates visual, organised work environment. Applicable to digital workspaces too - file organisation, code repositories, documentation.

tools.name: Gemba
tools.description: The gemba walk, much like management by walking around (MBWA), is an activity that takes management to the front lines to look for ways and opportunities to practice genba kaizen, or practical shop floor improvement.
tools.sovaContext: Go to where work happens. Leaders must observe actual work, not rely on reports. For startups: talk to customers directly, watch users use your product, sit with team members. Insight comes from the 'real place'.

tools.name: Just in Time (JIT)
tools.description: The just-in-time (JIT) inventory system is a management strategy that aligns raw-material orders from suppliers directly with production schedules.
tools.sovaContext: Inventory and production timing strategy. Minimise inventory by producing/ordering only when needed. Reduces cash tied up in stock. Relevant for physical product startups or service delivery timing.

tools.name: Kaizen
tools.description: Kaizen is a Japanese term meaning change for the better or continuous improvement. It is a Japanese business philosophy that concerns the processes that continuously improve operations and involve all employees.
tools.sovaContext: Continuous small improvements. Everyone contributes improvement ideas daily. Startup culture should embrace kaizen - compound small gains over time. More sustainable than big-bang transformations.

tools.name: Kanban
tools.description: An Agile management method built on a philosophy of continuous improvement, where work items are “pulled” from a product backlog into a steady flow of work. The framework is applied using Kanban boards—a form of visual project management. “To Do,” “Doing,” and “Done” are typical columns on a Kanban board.
tools.sovaContext: Visual workflow management. Limit work-in-progress, pull work when capacity allows. Simple To Do → Doing → Done boards. Less prescriptive than Scrum - good starting point for small teams.

tools.name: Poka-Yoke (AKA Zero Defects, Mistake Proofing)
tools.description: Poka-yoke is a Japanese lean manufacturing strategy that aims to eliminate mistakes and defects during the manufacturing process
tools.sovaContext: Design processes to prevent errors. Build checks that make mistakes impossible or immediately visible. Examples: confirmation dialogs, validation rules, checklists. Reduces reliance on human vigilance.

tools.name: Root Casue Analysis
tools.description: Identify the origin of a problem using a specific set of steps, with associated tools, to find the primary cause of the problem
tools.sovaContext: Systematic problem investigation. Don't treat symptoms - find and fix root causes. Combines multiple tools (5 Whys, Fishbone, etc.). Essential discipline for learning organisations. Every failure is learning opportunity.

tools.name: Andon
tools.description: A system which notifies managerial, maintenance, and other workers of a quality or process problem.
tools.sovaContext: Real-time status signalling system. Originated as factory lights showing machine status. Modern equivalent: dashboards, alerts, monitoring. Enables rapid response to problems. Transparency builds accountability.

tools.name: SMED (Single-Minute Exchange of Die)
tools.description: A system for dramatically reducing the time it takes to complete equipment changeovers.
tools.sovaContext: Rapid changeover methodology. Reduce setup/switching time. For startups: minimise context-switching costs, streamline onboarding, reduce deployment time. Every minute saved compounds over time.

tools.name: 5 whys
tools.description: An iterative interrogative technique used to explore the cause-and-effect relationships underlying a particular problem.
tools.sovaContext: Simple root cause technique. Ask 'Why?' five times to drill past symptoms. Example: 'Why did we miss the deadline?' Keep asking until you reach actionable root cause. Often reveals systemic issues.

tools.name: SIPOC
tools.description: A SIPOC (suppliers, inputs, process, outputs, customers) diagram is a visual tool for documenting a business process from beginning to end prior to implementation. SIPOC -- pronounced sigh-pock -- diagrams are also referred to as high-level process maps because they do not contain much detail.
tools.sovaContext: High-level process overview: Suppliers, Inputs, Process, Outputs, Customers. Quick way to define process boundaries before detailed mapping. Clarifies who provides what and who receives what.

tools.name: PERT diagram
tools.description: A PERT chart, also known as a PERT diagram, is a tool used to schedule, organize, and map out tasks within a project. PERT stands for program evaluation and review technique.
tools.sovaContext: Project scheduling with uncertainty. Program Evaluation Review Technique maps task dependencies and estimates durations. Identifies critical path. Useful for complex projects with many interdependencies.

tools.name: RACI
tools.description: Linear responsibility chart, describes the participation by various roles in completing tasks or deliverables for a project or business process.
tools.sovaContext: Role clarity matrix: Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed. Prevents confusion about who does what. Essential when scaling team or adding processes. Only ONE person Accountable per task.

tools.name: PEST analysis
tools.description: PEST analysis describes a framework of macro-environmental factors used in the environmental scanning component of strategic management.
tools.sovaContext: Macro-environment scanning: Political, Economic, Social, Technological factors. Identifies external forces affecting your market. Use for strategic planning and identifying risks/opportunities beyond your control.

tools.name: PESTLE analysis
tools.description: studies the key external factors (Political, Economic, Sociological, Technological, Legal and Environmental) that influence an organisation.
tools.sovaContext: Extended PEST: adds Legal and Environmental factors. More comprehensive external analysis. Particularly relevant for regulated industries or sustainability-focused startups.

tools.name: VRIO
tools.description: VRIO is an acronym for a four-question framework focusing on value, rarity, imitability, and organization, the criteria used to evaluate an organization's resources and capabilities.
tools.sovaContext: Competitive advantage assessment: Valuable, Rare, Inimitable, Organised? Resources meeting all four criteria provide sustained advantage. Use to identify and protect your unique capabilities.

tools.name: MoSCoW
tools.description: Prioritization technique for managing requirements. The acronym MoSCoW represents four categories of initiatives: must-have, should-have, could-have, and won't-have, or will not have right now.
tools.sovaContext: Requirements prioritisation: Must have, Should have, Could have, Won't have (now). Essential for MVP scoping. Forces hard decisions about what's truly essential vs nice-to-have. Prevents scope creep.

tools.name: OODA loop
tools.description: The OODA loop (Observe, Orient, Decide, Act) is a four-step approach to decision-making that focuses on filtering available information, putting it in context and quickly making the most appropriate decision while also understanding that changes can be made as more data becomes available.
tools.sovaContext: Rapid decision cycle: Observe, Orient, Decide, Act. Military origin but perfect for startup agility. Speed of cycling through OODA determines competitive advantage. Faster loops beat better-resourced slower competitors.

tools.name: Brene Brown - Dare to Lead, List of Values

questions.solo: I understand the minimum legal requirements to start testing my business idea safely (e.g., ABN, basic insurance)
questions.team: We understand the minimum legal requirements to start testing our business idea safely (e.g., ABN, basic insurance)
questions.keyTerms: Business Establishment Requirements: The essential legal and administrative steps to safely test your business idea in Australia. At Discovery stage, this means: ABN registration (15 minutes online), basic public liability insurance, understanding tax obligations. Full company setup, trademarks, and patents come later (after validating customers will pay). Free resources: business.gov.au starting checklist.
questions.advice:
Startups that skip legal basics face fines, shutdowns, and investor rejection. Get the foundations right before you start trading.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Sova Australian Startup Setup Guide: walks you through ABN, business structure, and registration essentials.
→ Business.gov.au Checklist: the official government checklist for starting a business in Australia.
→ Business Structure Guide: helps you choose between sole trader, partnership, company, or trust.

Complete the checklist, register your business, and keep records from day one.

questions.team: We have clear verbal agreements on ownership split, roles, and decision-making (with plans to formalise in writing once we validate customers will pay)
questions.keyTerms: Shareholder/Partnership Agreement: A legal document that defines who owns what percentage, who does what, and how decisions are made. IMPORTANT: In Discovery, focus on verbal clarity and mutual understanding. Formalise in writing (with lawyer review) when you reach Validation stage and have proven customers will pay. Early clarity is essential; legal formalisation should not delay customer validation.
questions.advice:
Handshake deals destroy friendships and businesses. Co-founder disputes are one of the top reasons startups fail.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Shareholders Agreement Template: a customisable legal document covering share ownership, decision rights, and exit terms.

Get your agreement drafted and reviewed by a lawyer before you build anything together.

questions.solo: I have a framework for making decisions (e.g., values, trusted advisors to consult, tools to research, books to read, skills to learn etc)
questions.team: We have a framework for making decisions (e.g., values, trusted advisors to consult, tools to research, books to read, skills to learn etc)
questions.keyTerms:
Core Values: The fundamental beliefs and principles that guide how you make decisions and run your business. They answer: 'What matters most to us?' Examples: Integrity, Innovation, Customer-First, Quality, Transparency. Strong values act as a compass when facing tough choices.
Decision Framework: A systematic approach to making choices in your business. Could include trusted advisors, decision criteria, research methods, or structured processes like RAPID (Recommend, Agree, Perform, Input, Decide).
questions.advice:
Startups fail when founders lack a support network and can't agree on how decisions get made. Don't go it alone.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Core Values Canvas: a collabourative workshop tool to identify 3-5 values that truly guide your decisions.
→ Brene Brown's Dare to Lead Values List: a comprehensive list to help you pinpoint what matters most.
→ Sova Experts and Networks Guide: helps you find advisors, mentors, and professionals who understand startups.
→ RAPID Framework: clarifies who Recommends, Agrees, Performs, has Input, and Decides on key choices.

Define your values, build your network, and document how decisions get made before conflict forces you to.

questions.solo: I have documented my business plan using a simple framework (Business Model Canvas, Lean Canvas, or one-page plan) explaining who I serve, what problem I solve, and how I will make money
questions.team: We have documented our business plan using a simple framework (Business Model Canvas, Lean Canvas, or one-page plan) explaining who we serve, what problem we solve, and how we will make money
questions.keyTerms: Business Planning Framework: One-page document capturing core business assumptions. Options: (1) Business Model Canvas - works for any business, (2) Lean Canvas - for startups testing new ideas, (3) One-Page Business Plan - simplest for service/retail. All force thinking: Who are my customers? What problem do I solve? How will I make money? What are my costs? Takes 20-60 minutes.
questions.advice:
Founders who skip planning waste time and capital building things nobody wants.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Lean Canvas: a one-page startup-focused template that captures your riskiest assumptions.
→ Business Model Canvas: maps out all nine building blocks of how your business creates value.
→ Business Plan (business.gov.au): a more traditional Australian business plan format.
→ Mission Statement Guide: helps you craft a concise statement (under 30 words) of your purpose and unique value.

Complete a business plan template that resonates with your business, get feedback from an advisor, and keep updating as you learn.

questions.solo: I have hypotheses about what makes me different from competitors (and I'm testing which differences matter most to customers)
questions.team: We have hypotheses about what makes us different from competitors (and we're testing which differences matter most to customers)
questions.keyTerms: Differentiation: What makes you unique. Examples: Florist - sustainable/local flowers, same-day delivery, wedding specialist. Consultancy - industry focus, methodology, pricing model. Restaurant - cuisine fusion, dietary focus, live music. Plumber - transparent pricing, same-day service, 24/7. Test hypotheses: faster? cheaper? better quality? specialist? What YOU think matters might not be what CUSTOMERS value. Test and measure. Competing only on price is a race to the bottom.
questions.advice:
Startups that can't articulate their difference get lost in the noise. If you can't explain why you're better, neither can your customers.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Competitive Analysis Template: a structured approach to understanding your competitors' strengths and weaknesses.
→ Value Proposition Canvas: maps customer needs against your offering to find product-market fit.
→ Jobs To Be Done Framework: helps you understand what job customers are hiring your product to do.
→ Unique Selling Proposition (USP): guides you to define the one thing that makes you different.

Complete a competitive analysis and articulate your difference in one sentence. Test it with potential customers.

questions.solo: I have defined my core business hypothesis (who I serve, what problem I solve, how I'll solve it, how I'll make money) and my plan to test it in the next 3-6 months
questions.team: We have defined our core business hypothesis (who we serve, what problem we solve, how we'll solve it, how we'll make money) and our plan to test it in the next 3-6 months
questions.keyTerms: Strategic Hypothesis: A testable statement about your business model. In Discovery, you don't have enough data for multi-year plans. Instead, define: (1) WHO you think your customers are, (2) WHAT problem they have, (3) HOW you'll solve it, (4) HOW you'll make money, (5) Your ASSUMPTIONS that need testing. Create a 3-6 month roadmap with testable milestones (not a locked-in 1-3 year plan). Long-term planning comes AFTER you validate the model works (Efficiency/Scale stages).
questions.advice:
Most startups fail because they lack product-market fit. Before you build, you need to know what assumptions you're betting on.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Lean Canvas: a one-page template that forces you to articulate your riskiest assumptions.
→ Assumption Mapping: helps you prioritise which assumptions to test first based on risk and uncertainty.
→ Riskiest Assumption Test: identifies the single assumption that could kill your business if wrong.

Document your core hypothesis, identify your riskiest assumption, and design an experiment to test it this week.

questions.solo: I have tested my core offering with real customers (before full launch or heavy investment)
questions.team: We have tested our core offering with real customers (before full launch or heavy investment)
questions.keyTerms: Testing Your Offering: Start small and test with real customers before investing heavily. Examples: Florist - do wedding flowers for 3 friends before renting shop. Consultancy - deliver 3 pilot projects at reduced rate. Restaurant - run pop-up dinners before signing lease. Plumber - start weekends while keeping day job. SaaS - build simplest version. Online store - test with 10 products before stocking 1,000. Goal: prove customers will pay before making big commitments.
questions.advice:
Startups waste months building features nobody wants. Test your idea with real customers before you invest heavily.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Concierge MVP: deliver your service manually to test demand before building automation.
→ Wizard of Oz MVP: create the illusion of a working product while you operate it behind the scenes.
→ Landing Page MVP: test interest with a simple page before building the actual product.

Pick the simplest way to test demand, launch it within days, and learn from real customer behaviour.

questions.solo: I have talked to potential customers to understand their problems, how they solve them now, and whether they would pay for my solution
questions.team: We have talked to potential customers to understand their problems, how they solve them now, and whether they would pay for our solution
questions.keyTerms: Talking to Customers: Have conversations to understand problems before launching. Examples: Florist - chat to couples at wedding fairs. Consultancy - coffee with potential clients. Restaurant - talk to neighbours about missing food options. Plumber - ask homeowners about frustrations. DO NOT pitch. LISTEN 80%, talk 20%. Ask open questions. Learn if the problem is real and worth solving.
questions.advice:
Asking customers what they want is a trap. They don't know. Ask about their problems instead.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ How I Interview Customers: Strategyzer's guide to conducting interviews that reveal real customer insights.
→ The Mom Test: learn how to have honest customer conversations that don't just tell you what you want to hear.
→ Jobs To Be Done: understand what job customers are hiring your product to do in their lives.

Talk to potential customers about their problems and current workarounds before you build anything.

questions.solo: I have a marketing strategy aligned to Business Plan
questions.team: We have a marketing strategy aligned to my Business Plan
questions.keyTerms: Marketing Strategy: Your plan for how you'll reach potential customers, what message you'll share, which channels you'll use, and how you'll measure success. Not random posts  —  intentional, coordinated efforts.
questions.advice:
Startups that underinvest in marketing struggle to find customers, no matter how good their product is.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Marketing Plan (business.gov.au): a structured template for planning your marketing activities.
→ Value Proposition Canvas: maps customer needs to your offering so your message resonates.
→ Customer Persona: Y Combinator's guide to understanding who your customer really is.

Create a simple marketing plan aligned to your business model. Know who you're targeting and why they should care.

questions.solo: I have calculated costs, revenue projections, and cash needs before launching
questions.team: We have calculated costs, revenue projections, and cash needs before launching
questions.keyTerms: Financial Planning: Forecasting your money in and money out for 12-36 months. Helps you know what you'll need before you need it.
questions.advice: 29% of startups run out of cash from lack of financial planning. Separate business and personal finances (tax nightmares otherwise). Use Financial Modeling to project costs and revenue, create Pro Forma Statements to show projected financial position, and implement Cash Flow Forecasting to track when money comes in and goes out. Know startup costs, create 12-month cash flow forecast. Set up accounting software (Xero, MYOB, QuickBooks). Run out of cash = game over.

questions.solo: I have a plan with realistic cost estimates and timelines based on research (not guesses)
questions.team: We have a plan with realistic cost estimates and timelines based on research (not guesses)
questions.keyTerms: Realistic Planning: Using data and research to estimate. Rule of thumb: add 50% to time estimates, 30% to cost estimates.
questions.advice: Do not guess costs—research them. Use Financial Forecasting, Project Planning Tools, and a Cost Estimation Guide to systematically calculate expenses. Call vendors for quotes, check industry benchmarks (IBISWorld, Crunchbase), talk to other founders. Pad estimates by 30-50% (everything costs more and takes longer). Underestimating costs = running out of money before you can validate your business model.

questions.solo: I have enough money to take advantage of opportunities that come up
questions.team: We have enough money to take advantage of opportunities that come up
questions.keyTerms: Capital / Runway: Money you have available. Runway = how many months until you run out of money. Calculate: Total cash ÷ Monthly burn rate.
questions.advice: Implement proper Financial Planning with Runway Calculation and a clear Funding Strategy. Opportunity fund = 10-20% of total cash as buffer for unexpected opportunities (bulk buying discount, competitor fire sale, unexpected partnership). Separate from emergency fund (6 months expenses). If you don't plan for opportunities, you'll watch competitors grab them while you scramble for cash.

questions.solo: I use a simple system to track income and expenses (spreadsheet, app, or software)
questions.team: We use a simple system to track income and expenses (spreadsheet, app, or software)
questions.keyTerms: Money awareness - track income, expenses, and know your basic costs.
questions.advice: Don't mix personal and business finances—29% of startups fail from this. Open separate business bank account, use accounting software: Xero / MYOB / QuickBooks (Xero $30/mo, MYOB $27/mo, QuickBooks $25/mo). Use a Cash Flow Template to track money in and out, and implement a Unit Economics Calculator to understand profitability per customer. Categorise every expense properly (ATO requires it, and you need accurate data for decisions). Financial mess = tax nightmare + bad business decisions.

questions.solo: I track 3-5 SMART metrics (revenue, customers, website visits, etc.) that measure progress against the Strategic Plan
questions.team: We track 3-5 SMART metrics (revenue, customers, website visits, etc.) that measure progress against the Strategic Plan
questions.keyTerms: Tracking basics - monitor key numbers showing if things are working.
questions.advice: Startups fail from analytical thinking deficit - not confronting market data with business goals. Apply Key Metrics Selection to identify what matters, use a Simple Tracking Sheet to monitor progress, and establish Baseline Measurement before making changes. Pick 3-5 key metrics that show if plan is working. Track baseline before optimisation.

questions.solo: I regularly review my performance and honestly compare it to my goals
questions.team: We regularly review our performance and honestly compare them to our goals
questions.keyTerms: Data-Driven Decisions: Using actual numbers (not gut feeling) to make decisions. Weekly: review metrics → compare to goals → adjust.
questions.advice: Schedule weekly 'metrics review' (30 min): What went up? What went down? Why? What will you test next? Use Data-Driven Decision Making frameworks, Analytics Frameworks to structure analysis, and KPI Dashboards to visualise progress. 67% of founders track metrics but don't ACT on them. Create simple if-then rules: 'If CAC exceeds $X, pause ads and test new channels'. Metrics without action = vanity.

questions.team: We have all co-founders contributing equal time/effort, with ownership matching actual contributions
questions.keyTerms: Co-founder Equity: Ownership should match time/effort contribution. One full-time + one part-time with equal equity = time bomb. 24% of co-founder relationships dissolve within 4 years.
questions.advice: 24% of co-founder relationships dissolve within 4 years from misaligned expectations. If solo: Do skills audit - know your strengths/gaps. If team: Use Equity Structuring to divide ownership fairly, implement Contribution Tracking to document who delivers what, and create Founder Agreements to clarify roles. Define roles clearly, use equity vesting (earn over 3-4 years), document who's responsible for what. Written agreements save friendships.

questions.team: We have had explicit conversations about roles, time commitment, and long-term goals
questions.keyTerms: Expectation Alignment: Clear, written agreements about who does what, how much time, what success looks like. Prevents 'I thought you were handling that' disasters.
questions.advice: Co-founder breakups kill 23% of startups. Implement Co-founder Alignment processes, establish Working Agreements, and practice rigorous Expectation Setting. Have explicit conversations BEFORE committing: (1) Time commitment (full-time vs side hustle?), (2) Equity split (equal or based on contribution?), (3) Roles (who's CEO, CTO, responsible for what?), (4) Exit scenarios (what if someone wants out?), (5) Decision-making (who has final say on what?). Uncomfortable conversations now prevent explosive conflicts later.

questions.solo: I've done a skills audit (what I'm good at, what I'm not)
questions.team: We've done a skills audit (what we're good at, what we're not)
questions.keyTerms: Self-awareness - know your strengths and where you need help or development.
questions.advice: List all tasks your business requires (sales, marketing, product, finance, ops, legal). Use a Skills Audit Template to rate yourself 1-10 on each, apply Role Definition to clarify responsibilities, and implement an Equity Vesting Schedule if working with co-founders. Focus on your 7-10s (your 'zone of genius'), outsource/learn 1-4s (your bottlenecks). Solo founders fail when they try to do everything poorly instead of mastering their strengths and strategically filling gaps.

questions.solo: I know which business areas I can handle vs. need help with
questions.team: We know which business areas we can handle vs. need help with
questions.keyTerms: Self-awareness - know your strengths and where you need help or development.
questions.advice: Categorise every task using a Skills Audit Template and Role Definition framework, then implement an Equity Vesting Schedule for team members: (1) Core competency (only you), (2) Can teach someone else (document & delegate), (3) Must hire expert (legal, accounting), (4) Can automate (software). Focus 80% of YOUR time on category 1 (only you can do), systematically eliminate category 2 (document then delegate), budget for category 3 (pay experts), and automate category 4 (find software). Working IN your business prevents working ON your business.

questions.solo: I have basic steps written down (even if informal)
questions.team: We have basic steps written down (even if informal)
questions.keyTerms: Process clarity - understand your workflow and have simple, clear processes.
questions.advice: Document core processes even if simple using a Process Documentation Template, Workflow Mapping, and Simple SOPs. Process clarity = consistency. As you grow, undocumented processes create chaos and dependencies on key people. Start simple: flowcharts, checklists.

questions.solo: I complete work in a consistent order each time
questions.team: We complete work in a consistent order each time
questions.keyTerms: Process clarity - understand your workflow and have simple, clear processes.
questions.advice: Consistency = efficiency. If you do the same task differently each time, you'll miss steps, waste time troubleshooting, and can't improve it. Use a Process Documentation Template, Workflow Mapping, and Simple SOPs to create simple checklists for repeated work (Trello, Notion, Google Docs). Example: 'Client onboarding checklist' ensures every customer gets same quality experience.

questions.solo: I can describe my delivery process start to finish
questions.team: We can describe our delivery process start to finish
questions.keyTerms: Process clarity - understand your workflow and have simple, clear processes.
questions.advice: Map your end-to-end customer journey using Process Documentation Template, Workflow Mapping, and Simple SOPs: First contact → Sales → Onboarding → Delivery → Support → Renewal/Referral. Identify bottlenecks where customers get confused or you waste time. Fix the biggest bottleneck first. Every friction point costs you customers and money.

questions.solo: I have essential tools set up (email, file storage, basic software)
questions.team: We have essential tools set up (email, file storage, basic software)
questions.keyTerms: Essential tools - have basic tech and systems needed to do your work.
questions.advice: Startups over-invest in expensive technology before validating assumptions. Use a Tech Stack Selection Guide, apply MVP Development principles, and implement a Tool Evaluation Matrix. Build minimum viable first, test with real customers, then invest in tech. Choose tools that integrate (avoid tech debt).

questions.solo: I have a way to deliver my product/service
questions.team: We have a way to deliver our product/service
questions.keyTerms: Essential tools - have basic tech and systems needed to do your work.
questions.advice: Choose delivery method that validates your business model WITHOUT building custom software. Use a Tech Stack Selection Guide, MVP Development methodology, and Tool Evaluation Matrix. SaaS? Use no-code tools (Webflow, Bubble, Airtable). Service business? Use Calendly + Zoom + Google Forms. E-commerce? Shopify. Don't build what you can buy/rent.

questions.solo: I invest in technology only AFTER validating core market assumptions
questions.team: We invest in technology only AFTER validating core market assumptions
questions.keyTerms: Technology Validation Timing: Don't invest in expensive technology before proving people want what you're building. 6% of startups fail from over-investing in tech before validating marketing assumptions. Build the minimum, test with real customers first.
questions.advice: Classic startup mistake: Build it and they will come. Instead: Validate demand first (landing page + waitlist, pre-orders, manual MVP), THEN invest in technology to scale. Apply Lean Startup principles, use MVP Methodology, and implement Technology Prioritisation. Typeform + Airtable + no-code tools can run a $100k business before you need custom software.

questions.solo: I have documented my role, responsibilities, and current strategic hypotheses (aligned to my business planning framework)
questions.team: We have documented who does what, and our current strategic hypotheses (aligned to our business planning framework)
questions.keyTerms: Documented Roles & Strategy: Clear documentation of who does what and your current strategic direction. At Validation stage, this should be flexible - you are testing hypotheses from your business plan (created in Discovery), not executing a locked-in multi-year plan. Update it as you learn. Reference back to your Business Model Canvas, Lean Canvas, or one-page plan from Discovery and refine based on customer feedback.
questions.advice:
Misaligned expectations between co-founders create partnership breakdowns. Document roles and responsibilities before resentment builds.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Business Plan Template: from business.gov.au to document your strategy and who does what.
→ RACI Matrix: clarifies who is Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, and Informed for each task.
→ RAPID Decision Framework: defines decision-making authority so nothing falls through the cracks.

Document your roles clearly and revisit them quarterly as the business evolves.

questions.solo: I stay compliant with all taxes, legal requirements, and regulations
questions.team: We stay compliant with all taxes, legal requirements, and regulations
questions.keyTerms: Compliance: Following all the rules - paying taxes on time, meeting legal requirements, keeping proper records. Non-compliance damages your reputation and ability to get funding.
questions.advice:
Missing tax, superannuation, and insurance obligations damages your creditworthiness and can shut you down. Compliance isn't optional.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Sova Australian Startup Tax Guide: explains your tax obligations as an Australian startup.
→ Sova Australian Startup Tax Checklist: a practical checklist to ensure you meet all requirements.
→ Compliance Framework Guide: helps you structure appropriate compliance for your size and risk profile.

Set up your compliance calendar and review obligations quarterly.

questions.solo: I solve a real problem that mainstream customers (not just early supporters) will pay for
questions.team: We solve a real problem that mainstream customers (not just early supporters) will pay for
questions.keyTerms: Real Problem: Something customers actively struggle with and are willing to pay to solve. Not a 'nice-to-have' or something only your friends think is cool.
questions.advice:
It's easier to satisfy existing demand than create new demand. Most failed startups built something nobody needed.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Product-Market Fit Playbook: a six-step methodology for validating that your product meets real customer needs.
→ Lean Startup: build-measure-learn cycles to test your assumptions quickly and cheaply.
→ Golden Circle: Simon Sinek's framework for starting with why you exist, not what you sell.
→ Adoption Curves: understand which customer segments adopt new products first and why.

Talk to mainstream customers (not just early adopters) and validate that your problem is real and worth paying for.

questions.solo: I have talked to many potential customers (not just guessed what they want)
questions.team: We have talked to many potential customers (not just guessed what they want)
questions.keyTerms: Customer Research: Systematically interviewing 50-100+ potential customers to understand their problems, not just asking friends and family who will be polite.
questions.advice:
Lack of product-market fit is the leading cause of startup failure. You can't guess your way to understanding customer needs.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Customer Interview Guide: Y Combinator's guide to having conversations that reveal real insights.
→ Survey Tools: free tools to collect structured feedback from your target audience.
→ Customer Discovery Questions: a comprehensive list of questions for different stages of development.

Talk to at least 20 potential customers before you build anything significant. Document patterns, not opinions.

questions.solo: I have researched and tested competitor solutions to understand their strengths and weaknesses
questions.team: We have researched and tested competitor solutions to understand their strengths and weaknesses
questions.keyTerms: Competitive Analysis: Using competitors' products yourself, understanding why customers choose them, and identifying gaps you can fill.
questions.advice:
Entrepreneurs who skip competitive analysis build products that already exist or miss obvious gaps. Know your battlefield.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Competitive Analysis Framework: a systematic approach to evaluating how you stack up against competitors.
→ TAM, SAM, SOM: helps you size your total, serviceable, and obtainable market opportunity.
→ VRIO Framework: assesses whether your resources create sustainable competitive advantage.

Research your competitors thoroughly. Use their products. Read their reviews. Find the gap they're missing.

questions.solo: I have researched my market by talking to potential customers (not just guessing), analysing competitors, and testing assumptions with real behaviour (not just surveys)
questions.team: We have researched our market by talking to potential customers (not just guessing), analysing competitors, and testing assumptions with real behaviour (not just surveys)
questions.keyTerms: Market Research: Understanding customers, competitors, and market. Scale to your business: Local business (florist, cafe) - talk to 10-20 customers, visit 3-5 competitors. Consultancy - 20-30 conversations. Tech startup - 50-100+ interviews. Quality beats quantity. Test with behaviour (pre-orders, pilot projects), not surveys. People lie in surveys, reveal truth through actions.
questions.advice:
Surveys lie. People say they'll buy, then don't. The only reliable research is talking to real potential customers about real problems.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ How to Talk to Users: Y Combinator's guide to conducting customer conversations that reveal truth.
→ Market Research Guide: business.gov.au's framework for understanding your market.
→ Google Trends Alternatives: tools to track search interest and validate market demand.

Talk to customers about their problems, not your solution. Watch what they do, not what they say.

questions.solo: I regularly try small experiments, measure what happens, and learn from the results (rather than making big bets without testing)
questions.team: We regularly try small experiments, measure what happens, and learn from the results (rather than making big bets without testing)
questions.keyTerms: Small experiments: Low-cost, low-risk tests that can be run quickly without major resource commitment. Examples: testing two different email subject lines, offering a feature to 10 customers before building it fully, running a one-week pricing test.
questions.advice:
Validation from friends and family is worthless. Real validation comes from strangers who pay or commit.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Experiment Board: a structured canvas for designing, running, and learning from experiments.
→ AARRR Pirate Metrics: tracks Acquisition, Activation, Retention, Revenue, and Referral to measure real traction.

Run one experiment per week. Document what you expected, what happened, and what you learned.

questions.solo: I have tested different ways to find customers and know which ones actually work (based on tracking results, not guesses)
questions.team: We have tested different ways to find customers and know which ones actually work (based on tracking results, not guesses)
questions.keyTerms: Finding Customers: How do you get customers? Examples: Florist - Instagram, Google My Business, wedding fairs. Consultancy - LinkedIn, referrals, speaking. Restaurant - Instagram, food bloggers, Google reviews. Trades - Google Ads, local Facebook groups, vehicle signage. Test 3-5 channels, measure cost per customer for each, focus on what works. Track: How much did I spend? How many customers did I get?
questions.advice:
The founders who survive track their numbers obsessively. The ones who fail fly blind.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ 19 Traction Channels: a comprehensive list of ways to find customers so you can test what works.
→ Bullseye Framework: helps you prioritise which channels to test first.
→ Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC): understand how much you're spending to acquire each customer.
→ LTV:CAC Ratio: compares customer lifetime value to acquisition cost to know if your model works.

Test at least three channels, measure the results, and double down on what works.

questions.solo: I have evidence (pre-orders, paid pilots, letters of intent) that customers will actually pay
questions.team: We have evidence (pre-orders, paid pilots, letters of intent) that customers will actually pay
questions.keyTerms: Payment Validation: Getting customers to commit financially before you fully build. A 'yes, I'd buy that' is very different from actually buying.
questions.advice:
Launching without evidence of demand is gambling. Pre-sales, paid pilots, and letters of intent prove customers will actually pay.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Pre-sales Validation: techniques for getting customers to commit before you build.
→ LOI Templates: Letter of Intent templates to formalise customer commitment.
→ Pilot Program Framework: a structured approach to running pilots that prove product-market fit.

Get at least three paying customers or signed commitments before building anything significant.

questions.solo: I track whether customers actually use my offering and come back (not just counting first-time purchases or signups)
questions.team: We track whether customers actually use our offering and come back (not just counting first-time purchases or signups)
questions.keyTerms: Customer Success Metrics: Do customers get value and return? Examples: Florist - % who reorder within 6 months (target 30%+). Consultancy - % who hire for 2nd project (target 50%+). Restaurant - % who return within 30 days (target 20%+). Plumber - % who call back (target 40%+). SaaS - % who complete first action (target 30%+). Online store - % who make 2nd purchase in 90 days (target 25%+). Track behaviour, not vanity numbers.
questions.advice:
No matter how great your product, if users don't come back, you don't have a business. Track retention obsessively.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Good Activation Rate Guide: understand what activation means and what good looks like for your type of product.
→ AARRR Pirate Metrics: track Acquisition, Activation, Retention, Revenue, and Referral in one framework.
→ Activation Metric Examples: practical examples of activation metrics across different product types.
→ DAU/MAU Engagement: understand whether users are engaging with your product daily or just occasionally.

Set up tracking for activation and retention. If users aren't coming back, find out why before spending more on acquisition.

questions.solo: I allocate budget and time to marketing from early on (not waiting until launch)
questions.team: We allocate budget and time to marketing from early on (not waiting until launch)
questions.keyTerms: Marketing Investment: Dedicating 20-30% of resources to marketing from validation stage. Too little or too late is a top failure cause.
questions.advice:
Marketing can't be an afterthought. Startups that wait until the product is ready struggle to find customers.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Pre-Launch Marketing Tactics: strategies for building an audience before you launch.
→ Early Stage Marketing Guide: practical marketing approaches for resource-constrained startups.
→ AARRR Framework: the pirate metrics that help you understand your full marketing funnel.

Start marketing before you launch. Build an audience, test messaging, and learn what resonates.

questions.solo: I make more money than I spend each month, OR have at least 12 months of savings
questions.team: We make more money than we spend each month, OR have at least 12 months of savings
questions.keyTerms: Cash Flow: Money in vs money out each month. Runway: months until you run out of money. Minimum safe runway: 12 months. Under 6 months = danger sone.
questions.advice: 29% of startups run out of cash from poor planning. Implement Cash Flow Management, Runway Calculation, and Burn Rate Tracking religiously. Generate revenue even if not profitable yet. Equity without financial backing lacks credibility. Aim for 18+ months runway, burn rate visibility, know your unit economics.

questions.solo: I have explored funding options that don't require giving up ownership (loans, grants, revenue-based financing)
questions.team: We have explored funding options that don't require giving up ownership (loans, grants, revenue-based financing)
questions.keyTerms: Non-Dilutive Funding: Money that doesn't require giving up ownership/equity. Includes: debt, grants, family loans, revenue-based financing. Dilutive = giving up equity to investors.
questions.advice: Non-dilutive funding first: Use a comprehensive Funding Strategy that prioritises Non-Dilutive Capital and Government Grants. R&D Tax Incentive (Australia, 43.5% rebate on R&D costs), Boosting Female Founders ($25k-$120k grants), EMDG (export grants up to $150k), revenue-based financing (Lighter Capital). Raising equity = expensive (dilution, legal fees, time). Exhaust non-dilutive options first.

questions.solo: I pay people with cash (or cash + equity), not equity-only
questions.team: We pay people with cash (or cash + equity), not equity-only
questions.keyTerms: Equity Compensation: Paying with ownership instead of cash. Red flag if used alone - signals you can't afford to pay real money.
questions.advice: Equity-only = red flag for quality talent. Develop an Equity Compensation strategy that balances Cash vs Equity using smart Hiring Strategy. Pay market rate cash (or 80% cash + 20% equity). If you cannot afford to pay anyone, you are too early to hire. Exceptions: Co-founders with vesting agreements (earn equity over 3-4 years, not upfront).

questions.solo: I have a pricing strategy (not just guessing or copying competitors)
questions.team: We have a pricing strategy (not just guessing or copying competitors)
questions.keyTerms: Financial planning - set prices thoughtfully, plan spending in advance.
questions.advice: Do not copy competitors or guess. Conduct Profitability Analysis, use a Burn Rate Tracker, and develop a clear Funding Strategy. Use Value-Based Pricing: (1) Calculate customer value (how much time/money you save them), (2) Price at 10-20% of that value, (3) Test 3 price points (A/B test with different customer segments). If you save customer $10k/year, you can charge $1-2k/year. Pricing too low = leaving money on table + signalling low quality.

questions.solo: I start talking to investors 9-12 months before I need money (not when desperate)
questions.team: We start talking to investors 9-12 months before we need money (not when desperate)
questions.keyTerms: Fundraising Timing: Starting investor conversations well before you need money. Fundraising takes 6+ months. Starting when desperate = weak negotiating position.
questions.advice: Cash flow problems: run out before generating sufficient income. Develop a comprehensive Fundraising Strategy, maintain strong Investor Relations, and implement Capital Planning. Require ROI justification for all expenses. Start fundraising EARLY - waiting until cash crisis = bad terms or failure.

questions.solo: I review my data weekly and ask hard questions (no excuses or rationalisations)
questions.team: We review our data weekly and ask hard questions (no excuses or rationalisations)
questions.keyTerms: Data Confrontation: Honestly facing what your numbers tell you. No spinning bad news or making excuses.
questions.advice: Vanity metrics kill: inflated registrations, purchased followers, manipulated revenue mask poor fundamentals. Implement Data-Driven Decision Making, conduct regular Analytics Reviews, and practice Hypothesis Testing. Track what matters: revenue, retention, CAC, LTV, churn. Data should drive decisions.

questions.solo: I check my metrics before making decisions
questions.team: We check our metrics before making decisions
questions.keyTerms: Metrics-driven decisions - use these numbers to decide what to do next.
questions.advice: Data-driven does not equal data-paralysed. Use 70% rule: When you have 70% confidence from data, decide and iterate. Implement OKRs (Objectives and Key Results), build a KPI Dashboard, and use Google Analytics for tracking. Create decision rules: If CAC exceeds $X, pause ads. If churn >Y%, focus on retention before acquisition. If feature adoption <Z%, kill the feature or redesign. Framework prevents emotional decisions.

questions.solo: I have a system for collecting customer feedback (surveys, interviews, NPS)
questions.team: We have a system for collecting customer feedback (surveys, interviews, NPS)
questions.keyTerms: Customer feedback - regularly gather and act on customer input to improve.
questions.advice: Implement NPS (Net Promoter Score): How likely are you to recommend us? 0-10 scale. Survey after purchase, after 30 days, quarterly. Use Cohort Analysis to track retention patterns, measure Net Promoter Score systematically, and develop a Customer Success Playbook. Track: Promoters (9-10), Passives (7-8), Detractors (0-6). Follow up with detractors immediately (save the relationship), ask promoters for referrals/testimonials. NPS <30 = major problems. NPS >50 = strong product-market fit.

questions.solo: I've made specific changes based on customer feedback (and can point to examples)
questions.team: We've made specific changes based on customer feedback (and can point to examples)
questions.keyTerms: Customer feedback - regularly gather and act on customer input to improve.
questions.advice: Marketing channels have expiration dates. Don't depend on single channel. Customer service orientation: prioritising new acquisition over retention creates 'leaky bucket' - fix retention first.

questions.solo: I have access to the right skills and knowledge (through advisors, contractors, or my own learning)
questions.team: We have people with the right skills and knowledge to execute our business model
questions.keyTerms: Domain Expertise: Deep knowledge in your specific industry/area. 18% of startups fail from missing domain expertise, marketing knowledge, or technical skills.
questions.advice: 23% of startups fail from team problems: missing expertise (domain, marketing, technical), co-founder friction. Evaluate Team Composition, conduct Skills Assessment, and implement strategic Hiring Strategy. Network matters - lack of referral sources limits growth. Hire for gaps, not comfort.

questions.solo: I track my own performance: Energy levels, productivity, satisfaction
questions.team: We track our own performance: Energy levels, productivity, satisfaction
questions.keyTerms: Wellbeing check - regularly assess your energy, skills, and effectiveness.
questions.advice: Solo founder burnout = business death. Use a Performance Review Template for self-assessment, develop a Career Development Plan, and conduct regular Culture Surveys (even for solo founders - assess your own wellbeing). Track weekly: Energy (1-10 scale), Hours worked, Exercise (days/week), Sleep (hours), Satisfaction (1-10). If energy <5 for 3+ weeks, something must change. Red flags: working weekends consistently, skipping meals, sleeping <6 hours, no exercise, social isolation.

questions.solo: I follow my documented processes (they're not shelf-ware)
questions.team: We follow our documented processes (they're not shelf-ware)
questions.keyTerms: Consistent execution - processes run consistently, everyone knows their role.
questions.advice: Establish repeatable processes for customer delivery. Use SIPOC Diagram (Suppliers, Inputs, Process, Outputs, Customers) to map workflows, apply Value Stream Mapping to identify bottlenecks early, and implement 5S Methodology for organisation. Document core workflows systematically.

questions.solo: I know my role in my processes
questions.team: Everyone on the team knows their role in our processes
questions.keyTerms: Consistent execution - processes run consistently, everyone knows their role.
questions.advice: Map your processes (even if just you) using SIPOC Diagram, Value Stream Mapping, and 5S Methodology: What steps are ONLY you (core expertise, strategy, relationships)? What can be documented and taught (admin, routine tasks)? What needs expert help (legal, accounting)? What can be automated (software)? Focus YOUR time on high-value work only you can do.

questions.solo: I have the technical skills (or advisors) to build what my business needs
questions.team: We have the technical skills (or advisors) to build what our business needs
questions.keyTerms: Technical Capability: Skills to build your product/service properly. If you have technical gaps, hire fractional CTO or technical advisor. Don't fake it.
questions.advice: Startups often lack technical/professional expertise to build comprehensive business models. Develop Technical Competency through training or hiring, strengthen Business Modeling capabilities, and use MVP Development approaches. Use Agile/SCRUM for iterative development. Technical debt compounds - address it early.

questions.solo: My tools are integrated (data flows between systems)
questions.team: Our tools are integrated (data flows between systems)
questions.keyTerms: Consistent systems - follow systems regularly and they help workflow.
questions.advice: Eliminate manual data entry between systems. Apply Agile and SCRUM methodologies, maintain a Technical Debt Register to track issues. Use: Zapier ($20/mo, 100+ zaps), Make.com (formerly Integromat, $10/mo), native integrations (most tools connect to Salesforce, HubSpot, Stripe). Example: Typeform submission → Airtable row → email confirmation. Save hours/week.

questions.solo: I use them daily without friction
questions.team: We use them daily without friction
questions.keyTerms: Consistent systems - follow systems regularly and they help workflow.
questions.advice: If you avoid using your own tools, customers will too. Use Agile and SCRUM for continuous improvement, maintain a Technical Debt Register to prioritise fixes. Friction points: Too many logins (use SSO), slow load times (upgrade plan or switch), complicated workflows (simplify or find alternative). Every quarter: Use your product like a new customer would. Fix what frustrates YOU first.

questions.solo: I can communicate with customers professionally
questions.team: We can communicate with customers professionally
questions.keyTerms: Essential tools - have basic tech and systems needed to do your work.
questions.advice: Professional communication tools using Tech Stack Selection Guide, MVP Development principles, and Tool Evaluation Matrix: Business email (Google Workspace $6/user/mo NOT Gmail free), Video calls (Zoom $15/mo, Google Meet), Phone system (OpenPhone $13/mo, virtual number), Chat support (Intercom $74/mo, Drift). Gmail free account = unprofessional. Customers judge credibility by email domain.

questions.solo: I have implemented the legal requirements establish the business (e.g., business name registration, ABN, insurance, gst etc)
questions.team: We have implemented the legal requirements establish the business (e.g., business name registration, ABN, insurance, gst etc)
questions.keyTerms: Business Establishment Requirements: The essential legal and administrative steps to set up a business in Australia. Full company setup, trademarks, patents etc. Free resources: business.gov.au starting checklist.
questions.advice:
Legal gaps create liability and scare off investors. Your governance foundations need to be solid before you scale.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Sova Australian Startup Setup Guide: covers ABN, business structure, and registration requirements.
→ Business.gov.au Checklist: the official government checklist for Australian businesses.
→ Business Structure Guide: helps you evaluate if your current structure still fits your growth.

Audit your legal setup annually and before any major funding round.

questions.solo: I have written policies that guide daily decisions and my business governance
questions.team: We have written policies that guide daily decisions and our business governance
questions.keyTerms: Policy framework - simple policies for operations, money, ethical treatment.
questions.advice:
Without written policies, decisions become inconsistent and onboarding new people becomes chaos. Document how things work.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Australian Business Procedure Templates: free templates from Business Victoria for policies and procedures.

Start with your most repeated decisions and document them one by one.

questions.solo: I listen to expert advice and am willing to change my approach based on evidence
questions.team: We listen to expert advice and are willing to change our approach based on evidence
questions.keyTerms: Flexibility: Being open to changing your mind when data or expert advice suggests a better path. The opposite of stubbornly sticking to your original plan despite evidence it's not working.
questions.advice:
Stubbornness kills more startups than bad ideas. The founders who survive listen, learn, and adapt.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ Growth Mindset Guide: explains the difference between fixed and growth mindsets and how to shift.
→ Pivot Framework: a structured approach to knowing when and how to change direction.
→ Sova Experts and Networks Guide: helps you find advisors who will give you honest feedback.

Seek out people who will challenge your assumptions, not just agree with you.

questions.solo: I stay up-to-date with changing laws and regulations in my industry
questions.team: We stay up-to-date with changing laws and regulations in our industry
questions.keyTerms: Regulatory Compliance: Following laws and regulations (privacy, data, industry-specific rules). Compliance burden increasing, especially since GDPR 2018.
questions.advice:
Markets change, regulations shift, and businesses that don't adapt get left behind. Stay informed or get blindsided.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ AICD Regulatory Compliance Guide: explains regulatory requirements and how to stay compliant across sectors.

Subscribe to industry updates and set a quarterly review to check what's changed.

questions.solo: I regularly update my business governance with new learnings, feedback, trends etc
questions.team: We regularly update my business governance with new learnings, feedback, trends etc
questions.keyTerms: Compliance monitoring - regularly check following rules and meeting requirements.
questions.advice:
Most startups change their initial ideas significantly. Your governance needs to evolve as your business does.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
→ McKinsey 7S Framework: assesses alignment across strategy, structure, systems, skills, staff, style, and shared values.
→ Continuous Improvement Tools: methodologies for systematically improving your processes over time.

Review your governance quarterly and update when something isn't working.

questions.solo: I focus on my core offering (I say no to 90% of 'nice-to-have' features)
questions.team: We focus on our core offering (we say no to 90% of 'nice-to-have' features)
questions.keyTerms: Core Focus: Your main offering that serves 80% of customers. Trying to serve everyone with everything increases complexity and kills businesses.
questions.advice:
Saying yes to every feature request dilutes your core value. Focus beats feature creep every time.

Some recommended tools for you to consider and complete:
